That‚Äôs a problem I have.
The event: I want to explain my (possibly wrong) view, and then find out why it‚Äôs wrong.
The issue:
This can waste valuable time.
The fix:
Listen to the teacher (more believable other)‚Äòs view first. Once I learn what‚Äôs right, my case either (a) won‚Äôt matter or (b) will still be relevant. Then we can listen to my (potentially dumber) case and dissect it
And, as per Dalio: doing it the other way puts the emphasis on (what is less important) what the student sees, rather than on (what is more important) what the teacher is trying to teach

One contract (of the ES) from SPY 300 to SPY 450 would have made (4500-3000) times 50 equals 1500√ó50 = 15√ó5√ó1000 = 75,000.

Or, if you were holding from the breakout at SPY 340, you would have been down $20 on the SPY = 200 points twice while holding. That means, at your lowest point, you would have been down 200√ó50 = 10,000, and you would have been up (470-340) times 10 equals 1300 points, 1300√ó50=65k at the top.

What ulterior motive Ray Dalio could have in writing this book: making money isn‚Äôt likely the primary focus or the ulterior motive; however, humanizing himself could be. He makes very high-level executive decisions, meeting with the head of the IMF, so his goal could have to do with making people think that he‚Äôs not some remote, lofty figure; he‚Äôs just a man who happens to know and have learned a lot of things, so he is among those best equipped to make these decisions
